router

Issues.Title: Inject migration follow-up fixes
Issues.Body:
Includes the following fixes that came up as a result of running the `inject` migration against Material and the CDK.

### fix(migrations): add alias to inject migration
Adds a shorter alias to the inject migration.

### fix(migrations): remove generic arguments from the injected type reference
Currently if an injected type has type arguments, we copy it over together with the type arguments to inject, because `inject()` isn't able to infer the generic properly otherwise. E.g. if there's `constructor(el: ElementRef<HTMLElement>)` we produce `inject<ElementRef<HTMLElement>>(ElementRef<HTMLElement>);`.

These changes drop the generics from the `inject()` parameter since we're overwriting the type anyway. The example from above would become `inject<ElementRef<HTMLElement>>(ElementRef);`.

### fix(migrations): account for parameters with union types
This came up in Material where we had a `constructor(@Optional() foo: Foo | null)` which ended up producing incorrect code, because the union type was preserved.

These changes resolve the issue by picking out the first non-literal type from the union for the `inject` call.

### fix(migrations): unwrap injected forwardRef
Updates the inject migration to unwrap the `forwardRef` call in cases like `constructor(@Inject(forwardRef(() => Foo)) foo: Foo);`, because the `forwardRef` will type the initializer to `any` and it shouldn't be necessary.

Issues.Title: Allow NgOptimizedImage to work with predefined srcset
Issues.Body: ### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request? common ### Description Currently, if I have a predefined srcset and do not need srcset autogeneration, I cannot use that predefined srcset with NgOptimizedImage. This is particularly useful when image links are signed and returned by the backend server, rather than being generated on the frontend. Example of the predefined srcset: ``` https://images.com/signature/image.png/128 128w, https://images.com/signature/image.png/256 256w, https://images.com/signature/image.png/384 384w ``` The `ngSrcset` does not support a complete srcset with image links, it only supports a comma-separated list of one or more width/density descriptors. The issue is that while I can add `[attr.srcset]` for the image, NgOptimizedImage won't be able to work with it. For instance, if I have an image marked with `priority`, NgOptimizedImage will autogenerate preload link element without `imagesrcset`, basically omitting `[attr.srcset]`. It seems that it generates `imagesrcset` only when `ngSrcset` is used, which prevents the use of NgOptimizedImage with predefined srcset values. ### Proposed solution Allow NgOptimizedImage to work with `[attr.srcset]` or add support for NgOptimizedImage to be able to use predefined srcset within `ngSrcset`. Along the lines of: ``` ``` where `image.srcset` is just a string of ``` https://images.com/signature/image.png/128 128w, https://images.com/signature/image.png/256 256w, https://images.com/signature/image.png/384 384w ``` ### Alternatives considered To make it work right now, I had to come up with a custom image loader and a bunch of utility functions. With `image.srcset` defined as ``` srcset: { [key: string]: string; }; // key is image width, value is an image src ``` I have the following `` ``` ``` ``` export function getSrcSet(srcset: { [key: string]: string }): string { return Object.keys(srcset).map(key => key + 'w').join(', ') } ``` And this sort of custom image loader ``` export const predefinedSrcsetImageLoader: ImageLoader = (config: ImageLoaderConfig): string => { if (config.loaderParams?.['srcset'] && config.width) { let srcset: { [key: string]: string } = config.loaderParams?.['srcset']; return srcset[config.width]; } else { return config.src; } } ``` While this approach works, it requires additional effort and complexity that could be avoided with better support for predefined srcset values in NgOptimizedImage.

Issues.Title: perf(compiler): set encapsulation to `None` for empty component styles
Issues.Body:
Make it so that encapsulation for empty styles, styles containing only whitespace and comments, etc. is handled the same way as with no styles at all.

Components without styles already have view encapsulation set to `None` to avoid generating unnecessary attributes for style scoping, like `_ngcontent-ng-c1` (#27175)

If the component has an empty external styles file instead, the compiler would generate a component definition without the `styles` field, but still using the default encapsulation. This can result in runtime overhead if the developer forgets to delete the empty styles file generated automatically for new components by Angular CLI.

Closes #16602

Issues.Title: Add an option to disallow concrete root providers to be used in TestBed
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

core

### Description

Currently, `TestBed` will happily use any `providedIn: 'root'` dependencies, in addition to dependencies provided by the component under test, or in non-standalone applications, module providers. This makes it extremely easy to introduce concrete dependencies to the test environment and thus break unit test isolation.

### Proposed solution

Add an option to `TestBed.configureTestingModule` that removes root, component, and module providers from consideration. This will force developers to provide mocks (or at least consciously choose concrete implementations) for all dependencies of a component.

Dependencies internal to the framework, such as those used by `effect` will need to be excluded from this restriction as framework functionality does not need to be mocked.

### Alternatives considered

Another approach would be to add a validation method that no concrete user services have been injected, similar to `HttpTestingController.verfiy`. I feel that putting it upfront rather than a testing assertion is more readable and harder to make a mistake with, but if the implementation of such a method is easier then it is a valid solution to the problem.

Issues.Title: esbuild: Using Tailwind breaks stylesheet processing for CSS @imports with URLs ending in .css
Issues.Body:
### Command

build

### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

When Tailwind is configured in a project (maybe just PostCSS), any `@import url()` statement with a URL ending in `.css` (such as `@import url(https://fonts.googleapis.com/earlyaccess/notokufiarabic.css);` causes the build to fail, as the url is deemed a local file by the language filters passed to [`StyleSheetPluginFactory.create()`](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/048df34ccb7d4ef67b5877e126c74c0db65b879c/packages/angular/build/src/tools/esbuild/stylesheets/bundle-options.ts#L59-L61). The `create` method seems to register an esbuild `onLoad` handler that will [read the path as a local file](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/048df34ccb7d4ef67b5877e126c74c0db65b879c/packages/angular/build/src/tools/esbuild/stylesheets/stylesheet-plugin-factory.ts#L167-L170)

Any URLs ending in `.less`, `.scss` or `.sass` are also affected.

In our case we can't easily remove `.css` from the imported URL, as it's defined by an imported third party CSS file.

### Minimal Reproduction

1. Create a new project with `ng new`
2. Install Tailwind by following the [Tailwind + Angular installation guide](https://tailwindcss.com/docs/guides/angular)
3. Add the following to `src/styles.css`: `@import url(https://fonts.googleapis.com/earlyaccess/notokufiarabic.css);`
4. Run `npm run build`
5. The build fails, as the URL is attemped to be read as a local file

When no Tailwind config file is present, the build runs fine:
1. Remove `tailwind.config.js` and the `@tailwind` lines from the CSS file, while keeping the `@import url()`
2. Run `npm run build`
3. The build succeeds

### Exception or Error

```text
ENOENT: no such file or directory, open 'https://fonts.googleapis.com/earlyaccess/notokufiarabic.css' [plugin angular-css]
```

I have followed the documentation steps mentioned in [Developer.md](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/main/docs/DEVELOPER.md). After running `yarn build --local` the package.json file for every scope(i.e. cli, build, pwa, etc..) have incorrect paths to npm_package_archive.tgz

Steps to reproduce
1. Clone the [angular cli repository](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli). 
2. Run `yarn build --local`
3. Open the dist folder and extract _angular_cli.tgz (Using this as an example you can look for any other tgz file in dist)
4. Open the `package.json` file
5. Look for `@angular-devkit/architect` (Using this as an example)
6. You will observe that the path to the file is something like: `<path>\packages\angular_devkit\npm_package_archive.tgz`
7. The same thing can be observerd in many places in this package.json file, and in other package.json files of other generated `<package>.tgz`

In Angular Material 18.1.x, when using a Material 3 theme, the `mat-divider` component uses the `outline` token instead of the `outline-variant` as specified by the Material 3 guidelines. Additionally, this creates inconsistency in places where we combine custom styles that set the color of outlines by using the `outline-variant` role from the theme, and also have `mat-dividers` within.

https://m3.material.io/components/divider/accessibility
https://m3.material.io/components/divider/specs#f7d1605e-1629-404c-86a5-0ef6848ce520
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/5161b955-a4ff-4cdc-9d09-d1b1ca807908)

### Feature Description
